instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
Hi!
I'm an electronics student from Austria trying to fix a Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> from a friend of mine. He took it to an Apple store and they said it is a liquid damage and wanted to charge him 1300€ for a new logic board. Thus, he asked me if I could fix it. I have watched numerous videos from Louis on the "stuck at 5V" topic and started investiagting the issue
Here is a short summary of what I've done so far. 

A visual inspection did not gave any obivous hints to a damaged part.
First I've checked the USB port and noticed that it got stuck at 5V and draws approx. 20mA. As suggested in multiple videos, I've measured the voltage rails around the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5V and is present at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>,
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = ~0V 

Then I've checked the supply rail of the USB-C port controllers, which was 0V.
--> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = ~0V
but the enable signal from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was present. Thus, I've checked if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted, which it was. As suggested in a video by Louis, it is very likely, that a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is responsible for this short, UB300. Thus, I've supplied 3.3V into the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> rail and identified the faulty <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> with the "alcohol on chip" method. Then I desoldered this chip and the short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> was gone. I ordered a replacement and soldered it in. 
However, the issue remained. The two ports, including the one I've fixed, stayed at constant 5V/20mA, but the other two ports did power cycle like in this video.
[MEDIA=youtube]vXAK2l1oMZM[/MEDIA]
Louis replaced the TB SPI Flash chip in this video and resolved the issue. I was not sure if a fresh chip from Mouser will do the job or if it needs some pre flashed data. Anyway, I ordered fresh SPI Flash chips and gave it a shot. After I've desoldered <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, these two USB-C ports did not power cycle any longer and this behavior persited after I soldered the fresh chip from mouser.

However, I've got stuck at this point and would need some further advice. First I've thought that the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> could be the problem, as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not present, I've replaced it but it did not change anything. Could there be another faulty <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> or could it be a faulty SMC chip?

Board Rev.: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

Thanks in advance!
Kind regards
Michael

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Put back <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, it has firmware.

You said liquid damaged board, but ehere???
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> after replacing one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?
Did you solder <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> with the same code termination (C00, B03)?
Compare diode mode readings on all LDO rails for all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

If battery still holds some charge, check if board starts on battery alone.
Be aware, need to press power button in this case; use SW5200 pads instead.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message: Don't touch the side that's power cycling, it's fine. It's the other side that's stuck at 5V without cycling that's causing trouble.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
Thanks for the quick reply!

I put the original <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> back and this side power cycles again.

Regarding the liquid damage, Apple claimed this and my friend told me that he spilled some beer over it, one year ago. After that, the machine worked but stopped working a few weeks ago. Since then, it won't boot.

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present, ~3.4V
I ordered the exact same replacement, C00. 

Supply/LDO Rails - Diode Tests:
UB300
    CB300: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 1.196V
    <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.40V
    Diode Test on LDO Rails:
    <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB308: 1.405V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB306: 1.313V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB305: 1.305V
UB400
    CB400: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 1.196V
    <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.40V
    Diode Test on LDO Rails:
    <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB408: 2.249V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB406: 1.219V    
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB405: 1.128V
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
    <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 1.196V
    <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.41V
    Diode Test on LDO Rails:
    <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR>: 2.269V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3106</CAPACITOR>: 1.226V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>: 1.23V
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
    <CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 1.196V
    <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.41V
    Diode Test on LDO Rails:
    <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR>: 1.404V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR>: 1.265V
    <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3205</CAPACITOR>: 1.264V

Unfortunately, the battery is empty, I got 0V when I measured the two pads which connect to J6950.

Thanks!
Michael

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
Looks to have a problem with <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.
Its  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>  has much lower value than rest of the chips.

You forgot to check 1V1 LDO, which is the most important.

BTW, any reason to check <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> in so many points?
Do you really expect to get different values in the same rail???

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
Sry, here are the values for the 1V1 LDO rail:

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on CB304: 1.816V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on CB404: 2.685V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR>: 2.705V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3204</CAPACITOR>: 1.817V

So that means <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and the one I've already replaced UB300 are faulty. Could it be that I've messed up some connections of the UB300 while soldering, or do you think it is dead?

Just wanted to document that the rail is available for all the four chips, would not expect any different values..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
"I've messed up some connections of the UB300 while soldering"
Do you have now some bad solders/traces there???

Please, do not write the end "V", when you post diode mode reading.
We don't need more confusion.

And re-check all the values.
Keep in mind, ALWAYS connect red probe at ground for diode mode!!!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
" "I've messed up some connections of the UB300 while soldering"
Do you have now some bad solders/traces there??? "
No, I meant that there might be some shorted pads under the BGA.

Thanks for the advice on the diode mode reading, did wrong before. Here are the new values:

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
Values look very similar.
Please, STOP to check the same rail in different points (<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>).

You must be sure UB300 is correctly soldered.
Also be aware of fake chips from chinese sellers...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message: Check the voltage on the LDOs as well.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 67709, member: 682"]
Also be aware of fake chips from chinese sellers...
[/QUOTE]

Yep, learned that lesson. Also a lot of these reballed ones i have found to be faulty. missing 1V1 LDO indicates bad controller chip

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
[QUOTE="piernov, post: 67714, member: 1057"]
Check the voltage on the LDOs as well.
[/QUOTE]
The 3V3 and both 1V8 LDO rails are ok on all four chips, but the 1V1 rail is missing on all of them. Do you think that all four chips are faulty, or could it be the capacitors that are connected to these rails?

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 67709, member: 682"]
Also be aware of fake chips from chinese sellers...
[/QUOTE]
I bought my replacement from a german macbook/iphone repair shop and it came in a sealed cut reel strip, so I guess they are ok, but you never know..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message: 1V1 LDO voltage must appear only on the chip where the charger is connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message: I've checked all the 1V1 LDO rails again, with the charger on each port. The <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are fine, they power cycle and I've measured 1.1V on each 1V1 LDO rail. However, the 1V1 LDO rail is missing on the other two <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (UB300, UB400). So I guess they are both faulty. Even the one I've replaced. Do you have any suggestions on where to buy good CD3215C00 chips? Shipping costs from the US (store.rossmanngroup.com) are fairly high, but if there aren't any alternatives, I would go for it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
I prefer to buy "board wings" from China.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32957303042.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.ca4d68e5TP4eDN&algo_pvid=0ea01f65-621b-4d43-995d-cc874dae4657&algo_expid=0ea01f65-621b-4d43-995d-cc874dae4657-10&btsid=0b0a050116050864653645152edee5&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_,searchweb201603_[/URL]
Buy more, as some of them may have these chips burnt; 10-15% failure rate is expected.
But you can be sure the chips are original.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message: Thanks a lot for all your help! Now I can only wait till the chips and a stencil arrive..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message:
UB300/UB400 work in master/slave mode. The master <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (UB300) must be able to read the firmware from the TBT ROM (UB090) for its 1.1V BMC LDO to come up and then USB-PD negotiation to start. The slave <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (UB400) gets the firmware from the master <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (UB300). So if UB300 doesn't work, UB400 won't work either. (I'm not sure if UB400 could cause UB300 not to work but it's a possibility.)

In any case it's most likely just bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Liquid Damage - Stuck at 5V on USB
threads.message: Wing boards have finally arrived, any tips on how to proceed? They seem to have some "underfill". My plan would be to fix UB300 first, replace it with a reballed replacement chip and check for the 1.1V BMC LDO.
